dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old, wooden sign in front of an equally old but sturdy salt of the earth church with a towering steeple. This is GRACE BAPTIST CHURCH of Gatlin, Nebraska and the sign proclaims the topic of today's sermon: CORN DROUGHT AND T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the choir music continues, picking up the DOORS TO THE CHURCH as they open to allow the CONGREGATION to exit.

dialogues.speaker: A CHILD'S POV
dialogues.text: We see only the legs of pants and hems of dresses from th little person's perspective. The parishioners are in thei "Sunday" clothes. We don't see the upper bodies or faces. OVER THIS SHOT we hear:

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: I don't remember everything that happened cuz I was only five then and now I'm eight.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHURCH ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: An adorable little boy of about five, his hand firmly in grasp of an adult's hand, is led out of the church. This JOB, and he is dressed appropriately for worship. He come to his father's waist, and this is all we see of the fath and the MINISTER in front of whom the father stops for a BEAT. Job stands there looking around while his father apparently talks with the minister. Legs continue to file past them.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: I was about the only kid in church that day, on account of all the other kids had been excused to go listen to Isaac, who was this boy preacher who'd come to Gatlin a few days before.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: AN ADULT, also whom we only see from the WAIST DOWN, bang into Job, who goes flying but doesn't fall because the strong hand of his father hangs on to him and lifts him i the air, setting him back down in place again. THE HAND of THE MAN WHO BUMPED HIM gives Job a vigorous apologetic rub across the hair.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: Sarah was home sick with mom. Dad decided to take me so he could talk about the drought with some of the other men. That's all everybody was talking about then, the drought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father finishes his brief conversation with the minister starts down the steps with Job. It's hard for little Job keep up with his dad and he's constantly whisked off his whenever he lags too far behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is pushed open by the unseen hand of his father Job is led into the coffee shop. Hansen's is a small, comfortable, homey place that caters strictly to the loca The furnishings are modest but everything is clean and ne Booths with red vinyl cushioning line the walls and the f holds eight or ten tables. There are also stools at the Formica counter, behind which MR. and MRS. HANSEN work busily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffee shop is crowded, mostly with ADULTS but also w A HALF DOZEN BOYS between the ages of 15 and 18. The two waitresses, SALLY and MARIE HANSEN, are about 17. They ar being kept quite busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four of the boys are crowded around a video MACHINE. They keeping very much to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job's father lifts him onto a stool at the counter and wa towards the PAY PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: Dad was worried about Sarah, so he went over to the phone as soon as we got in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS JOB'S FATHER as he walks across the room t the pay phone. We never see him fully, only the fact that is very average and non-descript. As he passes the four boys at the machine, one of them lo up and follows him with his eyes. This is WILLIAM RENFREW

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: There were some other kids there. I thought they were all in the corn with Isaac. Billy Renfrew looked at my dad, then smiled at me kinda funny.

dialogues.speaker: RENFREW
dialogues.text: After studying Job's father for a beat, he turns his gaze Job and smiles in a malignant, leering way.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: He averts his eyes quickly and spins on the stool so he w have to return the older boy's look.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: Dad sure was taking a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STRAWBERRY SHAKE is set down with a loud bang by kindly Hansen, who smiles at how startled Job is by the noise. J glances up at him fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: JOB'S FATHER
dialogues.text: A concerned look on his face, he continues on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SARAH, an angelic blonde haired girl of four years, is tossing and turning in bed. Her face is feverish and flus

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING SARAH
dialogues.text: HER MOTHER is visible in another room on the phone, talki with her husband, Job and Sarah's father. Semi-conscious her fever, Sarah spills a box of CRAYONS and clutches a B one. Without looking, she begins scrawling on a piece of MANILA PAPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she's drawing is not yet discernible, just a patch o black in the middle of the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job is sucking with all his might on a straw protruding f the strawberry shake. He glances towards his father. Something catches his eyes and causes him to FREEZE.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Thru the window, beyond his father, beyond the boys by th Pac Man machine, stands ISAAC. A gaunt boy of 12, he has face right out of the Old Testament and eyes that burn li coal. He is dressed in black robes and a wide-brimmed hat is staring into - through -the coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The straw slips out of Job's mouth. He is frightened to d of the vision before him but he can't take his eyes off o Isaac. Few, if any, of the adults in the room take notice but the boys by the Pac Man do.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: They turn and scan the room full of adults.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY AND MARIE
dialogues.text: Look at the boys conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Has four cups of coffee on a tray. She slips a white powd into them from a packet in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TWO MORE BOYS
dialogues.text: Step out of the kitchen. They have "farm instruments" wit them — HAY HOOKS and SICKLES.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HANSEN
dialogues.text: Looks at the boys, confused by their presence.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Is now terrified, trembling as he continues to stare at Isaac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of whom have been drinking coffee, begin to gag and choke. They lurch forward out of their seats, gasping for breath as they fall. THE FOUR Boys All whip out hooks, knives, scythes and other deadly WEAP They block the door.

dialogues.speaker: JOB'S FATHER
dialogues.text: looks at the boys in complete bewilderment. For a moment forgets about the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: She is scribbling like mad, seemingly unaware of what she doing or drawing.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING
dialogues.text: It is beginning to take shape. A PERSON, a childish stick figure, but unmistakable nonetheless, pointing....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hansen raises his hands in a futile gesture to ward o sickle that is arching through the air towards him. The point of it buries in his chest and a splatter of blood h Job.

dialogues.speaker: JOB'S FATHER
dialogues.text: tries to pull A BOY off an ELDERLY WOMAN. He grabs the yo from behind but barely gets his hands on him when A HAND HOLDING A SCREWDRIVER plummets INTO FRAME and into his ba

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: screams but nothing comes out. It is a scream from the deepest part of his being, and it is silent. Mr. Hansen' blood is still sprayed across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the coffee shop has turned into a scene o complete carnage, with all of the adults who are still al being either cut down or finished off by the Children Of Corn. Chairs and tables are over-turned, dishes and glass broken all over the floor, and blood everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac, standing fixed in place, is gradually encircled by devoted followers. CHILDREN, from four to 19, gather arou him, instruments of death in their hands all dripping wit fresh blood. Like him, they face the coffee shop and wait

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: That's how Isaac came and taught us about He Who Walks Behind The Rows.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEE SHOP DOORWAY
dialogues.text: The largest, most muscular, and most murderous of the boy inside the coffee shop emerges, his BUTCHER KNIFE drippin with blood. This is MALACHAI. He remains there, looking d at Isaac.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: Isaac and Malachai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is still in bed but is resting quietly now. CAMERA ZOOMS IN SLOWLY to the PICTURE she has completed.

dialogues.speaker: THE PICTURE
dialogues.text: It shows stick figure representations of Isaac, surrounde the other children, facing Malachai. Behind Malachai is a large splotch of bright red where the coffee shop would b Although the drawing is obviously the work of a child, th is an eerie, primitive quality to it.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: That's when Sarah started drawing these pictures.

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF PICTURES
dialogues.text: All done by Sarah in the same crayon style as the one we just seen, they reveal part of the story of Gatlin, Nebra Some are captioned.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST PICTURE
dialogues.text: Shows a cornfield wilted and dry. A MINISTER with gray ha is holding a REVIVAL MEETING in a clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shows the same Minister from the previous picture being pushed aside and supplanted by the now familiar figure of ISAAC. The caption underneath reads: AND A CHILD SHALL LE

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT PICTURE
dialogues.text: Shows everyone at the meeting kneeling in prayer to Isaac who holds his hands aloft triumphantly. The corn all arou is large and green and glowing.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT PICTURE
dialogues.text: The Grace Baptist Church. Hanging from its steeple is the gray haired Minister from the first picture. His eyes bul horribly, almost comically, and his tongue is sticking ou caption at the bottom: THOU SHALL WORSHIP NO FALSE IDOLS

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT PICTURE
dialogues.text: A FAMILY, with the parents lying bloodied and dead next t happy, smiling children.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST PICTURE
dialogues.text: That of a HOTEL, a simplistic version in red brick with b windows, and a BLUE THUNDERBIRD prominently parked next t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT. It is red brick, two levels; a real li version of the hotel in Sarah's picture.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: A BLUE THUNDERBIRD sits quietly in the parking lot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light filters through the curtains of the room, w is a standard DOUBLE OCCUPANCY. There are a couple of suitcases lying around, some clothes scattered about, and STEVEN KING PAPERBACK on the night table. BURT STANTON, a attractive young man of 28, is lying in bed fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is sneaking through the room towards Burt. We do see who it is, but there is a sense of danger counter poi by the peacefulness of the sleeping figure. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY, STEADILY, TOWARDS BURT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the figure sneaking up on him reaches bedside and stan over him for a beat, then leans down closer and closer an with more danger and...FWWWWTTT!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt jumps up with a start. His girlfriend VICKY BAXTER i foot away from him shouting and blowing a party-blower in face. The feathered end of it unfurls and tickles his fac Vicky is about Burt's age, wearing a sexy, flimsy nightgo and a party hat. She throws her arms around her frightene lover.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, darling! She's giggling mischievously over the fright her little surprise has caused him, and assuages any damage done wit seductive kiss. Burt's heart rate begins a slow descent towards normal as Vicky hands him a SHEET OF PAPER, rolle into a scroll and wrapped in tissue with a ribbon around

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Present number one. Burt laughs self-consciously and takes the paper. He unwr and unrolls it and looks at what it is.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAPER
dialogues.text: It is a TUITION BILL from NORTHWESTERN MEDICAL SCHOOL. It stamped PAID in big, red letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta da!

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT
dialogues.text: Burt is as pleased as he is surprised, and he's very surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But honey, how...I thought your last paycheck....

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: It did. But I had a little nest egg I was saving just for this.... She pulls out another wrapped gift, this one a long, rectangular box.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: And this.... Burt can't believe the windfall. He opens the box with ev more self-conscious delight. He holds up a beautiful WATC His jaw drops. Vicky is equally delighted and excited by reaction.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Look on the back. Burt turns the watch over and looks closely.

dialogues.speaker: THE INSCRIPTION
dialogues.text: FOR BURT STANTON M.D. - My Darling - LOVE VICKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt pulls her close and kisses her tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh Vick.... After the kiss she reaches for a small CASSETTE PLAYER an punches the button. The mischievous smile returns to her face as she straightens up and prepares to serenade him. BARRY WHITE, singing LOVE DOCTOR, begins to play. Vicky silently mouths the words in a wonderfully ridiculous caricature. Burt starts laughing and Vicky can't keep a straight face. Burt hits her with a pillow affectionately  10. A KNOCK AT THE DOOR INTERRUPTS THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky makes no move to answer the door. In fact, she look as if it's completely unexpected. Burt, still in his unde shorts, walks over.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: BELL GIRL, (VO)
dialogues.text: Room service. Burt opens the door a crack and looks.

dialogues.speaker: THE BELL GIRL
dialogues.text: An exceptionally attractive YOUNG WOMAN is standing outsi the door holding a plate with a bran muffin on it. A SING CANDLE, lighted, sticks out of the muffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgetting he's wearing only his under shorts, Burt opens door and faces the bell girl. She makes no move to enter instead starts singing HAPPY BIRTHDAY.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Is obviously attracted to her, almost to the exclusion of Vicky, who arranged the whole thing. He stares at the you woman, waiting for her to finish.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING VICKY
dialogues.text: When the bell girl does finish, Burt is beside himself looking for a couple of dollars to give her as a tip. Vic watches, as he fumbles through his pants pockets, the bel girl not completely oblivious to his attentions.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Watches quietly as he hands the woman the tip. There isa hurt, knowing expression on her (Vicky's) face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky are on the road in the blue T-bird. The ba seat is filled with CLOTHES, SPORTING EQUIPMENT, A COOLER PAPER BAGS, etc., and empty FAST FOOD CONTAINERS AND WRAP are threatening to overflow from a garbage bag and the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (Contrite) C'mon, honey. You're making something out of nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: To me it’s something. To you it is nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How would you like to be standing around in your underwear while some cute guy sang you happy birthday?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (Relenting) I wouldn't mind if it was you. As a matter of fact, it sounds kinda kinky. She gives him a slightly grin, which he smiles at. The tension evaporates. Burt reaches across the seat and hugs to him, driving with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I know what you're thinking. You put me through med school, I'm on my way out to a good internship position in California, and now maybe I don't need Vicky so much anymore. Right? Her silence answers affirmative.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Wrong. I still need Vicky as much as I always have, and I love her very much. Maybe I'm not as ready to settle down as you are, but that doesn't mean I love you any less. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Got it.  12. He gives her a reassuring hug.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Good. Welcome to Nebraska. Vicky looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A large official sign welcoming drivers to the state. WEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It continues past the sign, burrowing into a vast sea of cornfields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have seen glimpses of Gatlin before, but things now - three years later - are far more tranquil and idyllic. It just a tiny farm community not even on the map, out in th middle of nowhere. Like everything else in this state, it surrounded by cornfields.

dialogues.speaker: A BARN
dialogues.text: stands at the edge of where the cornfield meets the town. Three children are hiding behind it, pressed against the side. They are Job and Sarah, whom we've met, and JOSEPH, is much older and larger at 14. All three are dressed in black cloth clothes of simple design, not unlike the Amis Mennonites. Joseph has a suitcase with him and appears extremely nervous, to the point of desperation. As CAMERA MOVES IN SLOWLY, we hear JOB'S CONTINUING VOICE OVER NARRATIVE.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: We were with Joseph when he ran away. He was pretty scared. I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: (whining, frightened) I'm scarrrrrred!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Me tooooooo.  13.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be afraid of. I said I'd come back for you. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Can't we go with you? Pleeeease?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: No! I'd never make it with you two.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: But we don't like it here!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I said you'll be alright. (beat) As long as nobody finds them pictures you been drawing. Sarah averts her eyes and tugs sheepishly at her dress.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: She can't help it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: That won't matter to Isaac and Malachai. They'll take it asa sign. Anyway, you know crayons and drawings are forbidden.... just like having a record player.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: But we like it! Isaac doesn't let us do anything.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Well you just better mind him 'til I get back, or else you know what happens. He punctuates his conversation with constant glances towa the town and, more particularly, the corn. Job picks up o this.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: You're not goin' through the corn are you? This apparently bodes ill. Joseph swallows hard and looks out over the field.  14.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD
dialogues.text: It is serene, but dense and unyielding. A threat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Can't go no other way.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: But what about....? She doesn't finish. She doesn't need to.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: It'll be alright, unless you tell anybody I'm gone.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: We won't.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Cross your heart and hope to die, stick a needle in your eye?

dialogues.speaker: JOB AND SARAH
dialogues.text: nod in agreement like two good little soldiers. They cros their hearts with their fingers and then motion as if sticking something in their eyes. It is a children's oath taken in the way of children - with the utmost solemnity sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Okay. You know what that means. If you tell you're gonna burn on the lake of fire for all eternity. Their eyes widen in fear at the prospect. Joseph turns hi attention to the cornfield. He's sweating profusely.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Make sure nobody's looking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job and Sarah race to the town side of the barn and look cautiously around. Simultaneously they shout back to Jose at the tops of their lungs.  15.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: He cringes at the volume and rolls his eyes in disbelief. deep breath and he's off into the corn.

dialogues.speaker: JOB AND SARAH
dialogues.text: They stand there watching disappointedly as their friend makes good his escape. They remain fixed, frightened and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, flat, straight, strip of black tape separating a of golden-tipped, green corn on either side. There is something alien, remote, about this landscape. A DOT appe in the distance, growing larger.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOT
dialogues.text: Becomes the blue Thunderbird, which whips by. CAMERA FOLL IT, picking up a faded WOODEN SIGN by the roadside.

dialogues.speaker: THE SIGN
dialogues.text: Reads GATLIN 7 MILES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky are bored and quiet, lost in separate thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Deserted, dilapidated, a roadside skeleton that hasn't be attended in years.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So now we know. The back roads are even less interesting than the highway. Vicky smiles sympathetically. She reaches for the radio.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Maybe they've discovered music...  16. She flips the knob and a PREACHER'S VOICE fills the car

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (VO)
dialogues.text: Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: BURT AND VICKY
dialogues.text: Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (VO)
dialogues.text: The Lord has said that there are many mansions in His house. But there's no room there for the fornicator! Burt and Vicky give each other a look. This is a goof.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION, (VO)
dialogues.text: (loud)

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (VO)
dialogues.text: No room for the hommasexshull!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (VO)
dialogues.text: No room for the abortionist, nor the drug abuser, no room for rock and roll music!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (VO)
dialogues.text: When are they gonna find out that the wages of sin are paid in the hot, hot halls of... Vicky turns the dial sharply before the preacher can fini All she gets is static.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Hallelujah, amen, peanut butter, white bread, and Donnie and Marie.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No room for the college graduate! No room for people who watch public television!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: No room for commitments.  17.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph is running scared through the corn. He struggles against the thick, unyielding stalks and is sweating and breathing heavily. He stops every few yards to listen for sounds of pursuit and also to get his orientation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, changes direction, stops again and looks up at sun. He is lost and fighting against his panic. The corn begins to RUSTLE ominously. Joseph does an abrupt about f and runs face first into a heavy ear. It thuds against hi cheek, raising a welt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It continues to run the steady, gauntlet of corn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA IS LOOKING OUT FROM the cornfield, as if the plant themselves were watching. The car goes by.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD ON
dialogues.text: With the approaching vehicle. It abruptly slows down and pulls over onto the narrow shoulder that separates the asphalt from the corn. There is a claustrophobic sense ab proximity of the stalks. Burt’s door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt gets out. Vicky remains inside but the windows are o

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Corn looks a little dry.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Can I watch?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Better not. It leads to insanity.  18. He walks up to the wall of corn. It's imposing, and it st him.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That's okay. I'm crazy about you anyway. Burt is transfixed by the corn. He doesn't respond, or ev turn around.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Burt? Is anything wrong? That snaps him out of it. He looks back at her and smiles

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No. Be back in a sec. He starts to go into the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corn rustles ever so slightly in front of him, but th is no breeze. Burt stops like he's just walked into a wal of glass.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) Did you see that???

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING VICKY
dialogues.text: She's still in the car, leaning out the window.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: No. What? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I guess it was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh boy! Somebody's been in the car too long.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (not convinced) Yeah.  19. With a hint of apprehension, he submerges into the field. swallows him instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph is utterly terrified. He's moving quickly through corn, suitcase in hand, like someone who knows he's being followed. He hears what sounds like giggling up in front him. He runs to the side but is stopped by DELIBERATE and TAUNTING NOISES in that direction. The SOUNDS ARE GLEEFUL and seem to be made by children. Joseph turns again and again, but every-time is stopped. A circle is closing aro him. He is trapped, and covered with parts of corn plants

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky gets out of the car and walks towards the corn.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Burt? Are you alright? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Say something. Anything. I'm all ears. (beat) Burt, that was supposed to be funny. The only answer is a SOFT, RUSTLING SOUND from the impenetrable field. It's almost like a whisper, and it spooks Vicky a little.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: is standing in the corn listening to that rustling. Somet touches his shoulder and he whips around. A CORNSTALK is leaning on him. As he shoves it aside, A CORN LEAF pokes neck. Burt is starting to get agitated. He begins to RUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph is running also, but now with a sense of futility. His direction changes constantly and his terror is even greater than before. He trips over an ear of corn and fal down.  20. Before he can get up, A HAND ENTERS THE FRAME and grabs h by the shoulder. Joseph utters a squeak of fright, the so of a bird caught in a hunter's snare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is still running. The corn seems to be rustling all around him, but that might be from the commotion he's mak He shoves ears and stalks and leaves out of his way frantically. SUDDENLY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky crashes into him from the blind side. He grabs violently in a reflex reaction.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Well, if this is how it affects you, we’ll have to come here more often! Burt stares at her, catching his breath. He continues clutching her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Vicky!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You were expecting maybe Jaqueline Bisset? Burt wraps his arms around her. It is at once a gesture o relief, friendship, protectiveness and sensuality.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I knew you were kinky.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Why? Things are starting to get interesting. (beat) You alright?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I just got turned around a little. But let’s go.  21.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Okay.... He starts to guide her straight ahead. She pushes him on angle.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That way. They exit the cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: THE THUNDERBIRD
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky emerge from the cornfield and get into the car. Just before Burt ducks into the driver's side, he gi the corn a long, last look.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORN
dialogues.text: It is silent and still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt gets in and the T-bird drives away.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORN
dialogues.text: Begins to rustle quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph is flat on his back, panting and struggling, tryin get away from Malachai, who has pinned him to the ground a knee and an arm. Others must be holding Joseph by the f from the way he's stretched out. Corn silk is plastered t his neck and face, glued there by the sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CIRCLE OF CHILDREN tightens around Joseph. They begin humming in an eerie, atonal way. A HAND grips Joseph's ha and jerks his head back. The boy's eyes widen, a look of sheer terror coming over him. Malachai raises a cornhuske knife over him. The humming increases in intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safe within the car, Burt and Vicky have calmed down considerably.  22.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I don't know what came over me. I never had claustrophobia before.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Maybe it was just cornophobia.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It sure could’ve been that. I’m even ready to get back on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I think it wasn’t too far on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS the car as it slams past us from right to l It passes another old SIGN.

dialogues.speaker: SIGN
dialogues.text: In the shape of an arrow and made of rotting wood. It rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph is staggering TOWARDS THE CAMERA, which is PULLING BACK, KEEPING PACE. His eyes are blank and bulging. His hands are up to his throat and blood is flowing through h fingers, bright and sparkling. The front of his shirt is sodden with the red fluid. In effect, he's dead on his fe He's heading out of the cornfield although he doesn't kno it. Behind him we see a trail of twisted, broken corn pla with blood splashed on them. In the far background is Joseph's SUITCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky is fishing through the glove compartment, looking f the map. She has PAPERS, TISSUES, HAND-WIPES, A COMB, THE CAR REGISTRATION, everything in her hand but the map.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Here it is. She extracts it from a STUCKEY'S BAG on the floor. A WAD DRIED KETCHUP stains the front.  23. She begins unfolding it across the dash. She studies Burt with a knowing smile.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I wonder how it got in there....?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph, reeling like a drunk, comes to the edge of the cornfield. He looks inhuman, like a macabre doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky and Burt are studying the map, which partially obsc their view through the windshield. Vicky is pointing.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You see? This way goes to Grand Island, and this looks like it cuts out towards the highway.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Where's this "Gatlin" we've been seeing signs for?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's not on here. Burt leans over closer.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It has to be... Something causes Vicky to look up. ANGLE — VICKY Shock, then horror, registers on her face. She's speechle for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph staggers out onto the road, directly into the path the onrushing car. His hands are still at his throat and knees are already buckling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky barely has time to scream.  24.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Burt jerks his head up, sees the boy, hits the brakes and goes into a swerve all in one motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything happens extremely fast. Amidst the sound of screeching tires and brakes, the T-bird begins to skid. There's a loud THUMP as it strikes Joseph's body, which w crumpling even before impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car continues to skid and we can't see whether it actually runs over the body or just hits it, but we can s that it's in grave danger of overturning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is fighting the wheel. The tires are still screechin Vicky is one long, piercing scream. As the car comes toa shuddering, quivering halt, she is thrown face first into windshield. Burt, wearing his seatbelt, goes forward and sharply. There's silence except for the sound of the idli motor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt moves quickly. He rips off his seatbelt and cradles Vicky in his arms, examining the nasty bruise that has already formed on her cheekbone.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Are you alright??? Can you feel my hand??? Vicky hasn't really composed herself yet. She's whimperin softly. Burt runs his hand over her face.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: There's a contusion and swelling. It doesn't feel like anything’s broken.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That was an animal, right Burt? Please tell me it was an animal.  25. Burt suddenly remembers the boy.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I've got to go back there. You stay here and sit quietly. Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: REAR VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: Burt knows it was no animal he hit. He stares at the heap lying in the road about 100 feet back that is reflected i the mirror. He prays silently for a sign of movement, but there is none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt gathers himself quickly and bolts from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph's body lies face down, turned away from Burt, who kneels beside it. He puts his hand to the boy's neck, fee for a pulse, and is confused when he withdraws his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BURT'S HAND
dialogues.text: It's covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt turns the body over. It flops boneless, lifelessly, its back. The eyes are open and we can see very plainly t Joseph's throat has been cut from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT
dialogues.text: Burt grimaces and loses his breath for a beat. Then he closes Joseph's eyes - a deeply tender gesture - and make momentary calculation. Vicky's voice interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Is he....?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky turns away suddenly and gags. Burt rushes to her.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh my God....  26. Burt comforts her and starts leading her back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Vick, there's something terribly wrong here. I want you to get in the car and wait for me, and keep the doors locked no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Why? What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when I get back. Just do what I say. Vicky is alarmed, both by what he isn't telling her and w he is.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: No! Where are you going??? They reach the car. Burt opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I have to get the body. And I want to look at something.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Vicky! Please! She debates for a beat, then slips into the car. terribly shaken and pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt opens the trunk and rearranges things to make room. He takes out a BLANKET, then turns and looks back at the body, and also takes out a TIRE IRON.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CORN
dialogues.text: She is Although we don't see who it is at first, someone watches Burt goes back to the body and gently covers it with the blanket.  27.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Walks over to the mangled portion of the cornfield where Joseph exited. He studies the twisted, broken and blood- covered stalks. All of his senses are alert.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD
dialogues.text: Deep in, he spots Joseph's suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt makes a decision. He checks the car, looks all aroun and finally, tentatively, walks into the corn-field.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING VICKY
dialogues.text: Vicky is in shock, resting dazedly in the front seat. Her head is back against the headrest and her eyes are closed She's sobbing softly. If her eyes were open, she would see Malachai emerge from corn about 50 feet ahead. She would see him pause, the bl cornhusker's knife still in his hand, and then approach t car. She doesn't see this, BUT WE DO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is moving carefully, alertly, through this jungle. He holds the tire iron ready and turns in every direction as moves forward. The suitcase is just up ahead in a clearin

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING VICKY
dialogues.text: Vicky comes out of her stupor and looks through the windshield. She sees Malachai standing in front of the ca with his malignant stare. VICKY SCREAMS and lunges for th car horn. She pounds on it, frantically looking behind he for any sign of Burt, then whips around to see that, Mala is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is kneeling by the suitcase. HE HEARS THE CAR HORN but doesn't respond immediately; perhaps thinking she is just getting impatient. The suitcase is in a clearing. There i much blood here, still fresh. The suitcase is splattered it. Suddenly, the corn begins to rustle in that weird way again. Burt looks up at the towering stalks. They seem to be closing in on him.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky is unglued. She gets out of the car, near hysteria. She begins to walk back towards the body.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Burt? Burt, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY'S POV
dialogues.text: There is no sign of Burt. No sign of Malachai either. In fact there is no sign of anyone or anything other than th endless, ubiquitous corn and the blanket covered body lyi stubbornly in the middle of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky approaches the body. She cups her hands to her mout and begins to cry. She is unable to take her eyes off of She kneels next to it.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (to body) You poor thing. You poor, dear boy. And suddenly, violently, Joseph lurches up, causing the blanket to fall away from his hideous, blood drenched bod and deathly white face. He reaches for Vicky's neck. She screams and jumps back, continuing to scream and back ped until....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone grabs her from behind and she whirls with a start finding herself face to face with Burt. She aborts anothe scream when she sees who it is.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Vicky! She stares at him, all the trauma beginning to be too muc for her. Burt realizes this. He puts down the suitcase an shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: VICKY!! VICKY!!! Get a hold on yourself! She flings herself at him. Burt holds her closely.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh Burt! Where'd you go??? I kneeled down next to...  29. She suddenly remembers and whips around.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH'S BODY
dialogues.text: It remains how and where it has been. The blanket covers TwO SHOT Vicky looks at Burt again, genuine confusion in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: He sat up. He tried to grab me...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (gentle, compassionate) It's alright. Everything's going to be alright. I'm here now. But the look on his face tells us he isn't quite convince himself. He hands Vicky the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Take this. Come on, we’1ll go back to the car. I’ve got to get the body.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Don’t go-leave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky takes the suitcase. Burt goes to the body, securing blanket under it. They walk grimly to the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky waits while Burt puts the body in the trunk along with the tire iron, which he's had tucked into his belt. Vicky hands him the suitcase in the front seat. He and Vi get in quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the t-bird accelerates down the road, dwindling out of sight, Malachai steps out of the cornfield. He stares aft the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot. An American Gothic, like many of the houses in Gatlin. CAMERA ZOOMS IN SLOWLY to an open windo We hear Job's VO NARRATION.

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: Me and Sarah were playing. We played lots. Malachai said it was forbidden, but I think it was cuz nobody liked to play with him anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job and Sarah are playing MONOPOLY. They're dressed to th hilt in the clothes of some former adult residents. The clothes are far too large and the garnishing far too elaborate, which make them perfect for these two hams. Jo swimming in a suit and tie outfit complete with hat, pipe a handkerchief in the pocket. He looks absolutely dashing Sarah is in a glittering gown, also a hat, jewelry and lo of makeup. A small, battery-powered record player is grin out TONY BENNET’S “I LEFT MY HEART IN SAN FRANCISCO” next them. On the floor by Sarah is a piece of manila drawing paper and a bunch of crayons. As they play.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: When I grow up I'm gonna have all the money in the world.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Cuz I'm gonna have it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'll get it first.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Will not.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Will too.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? How? Sarah PLACES A HOTEL ON BOARDWALK. Job's face registers shock and dismay, but Sarah is well within her rights, He picks up the dice and counts. A SEVEN will land him on th dreaded Boardwalk. He jiggles the dice and throws them.

dialogues.speaker: THE DICE
dialogues.text: A seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah giggles deliriously while Job counts off the spaces with his piece, THE COWBOY ON HORSEBACK. He purposely miscounts and places his player on GO. Sarah catches him immediately. She moves the piece back to its rightful pla on Boardwalk.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Uh-uh, Job.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: How much is it?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thirteen thousand, hundred dollars. She puts out her hand for the payoff. Job gives her twent and some ones. Still, it's painful for him to have to pay anything, least of all to her. He covers this up with a child's ploy: diversion. He grabs the piece on Boardwalk.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Let's pretend this is Isaac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places the piece on the board four spaces from the GO JAIL spot and throws the dice.

dialogues.speaker: THE DICE
dialogues.text: They total 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job quickly reaches down and changes the numbers so they out to 4. He and Sarah squeal with delight as Isaac is trudged off to jail.  32.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What if he gets a "Get Out Of Jail Free" card? Job quickly fans through the pile of CHANGE CARDS and extracts all of the GET OUT OF JAIL FREE CARDS. He tosses them over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: What cards? They're laughing and giggling at this when their fun is abruptly halted by a LOUD BANG.

dialogues.speaker: JOB AND SARAH
dialogues.text: They look towards the door at the same time. There is fea in their expressions.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAI
dialogues.text: Malachai stands there glaring at them, having slammed the butt end of his knife into the doorframe to get their attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aftershock. Burt is driving. Very fast. Vicky is still reeling from the imagined (?) encounter with Joseph. She becoming hysterical again.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ...and then he sat up and tried to grab me and I could see...Oh God...it looked like his throat had been cut.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You must have taken the blanket off and looked at him.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I didn’t! Why are you insisting that???

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Vicky, you must have. Otherwise how could you know? When I got there the blanket was covering him.  33.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: How could I know what? Burt realizes he’s given something away, and now he has t tell her what happened. He doesn’t know how to say it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Uh... Umm... About his throat.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How could you know that his throat was cut unless you lifted the blanket and looked? He’s beginning to wonder that himself. Could Joseph have risen up the way she described? It’s too farfetched for B but it chills him. Vicky is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Then it’s true! He did...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Don’t do it, Vicky. Don’t even think it. You’ve had a traumatic experience. You’re in shock. Now you’ve got to get a grip on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) But how could getting hit by a car...?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It didn’t. He looks at her grimly, allowing her to figure out for herself just how the boy died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very dark. Light filters in only through partially drawn curtains. The furnishings are sparse, austere, but good quality. There are religious artifacts all about, mo of a conspicuously pagan nature; knives, scythes, symbols hewn from corn plants, crosses; and in the middle of all sits Isaac.  34. He is less frightening now in this quietude, almost scholarly. He is writing something by the light of a sing shaft of sun that penetrates the room. One gets the feeli Isaac is a holy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malachai enters with Job and Sarah, still dressed in thei comical outfits. Isaac's and Malachai's clothes are in st contrast - the simple, black cloth we've seen before. Malachai salutes his leader with a touch of the knife to forehead. It is a pagan, barbarian gesture.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: I found these two in one of the old houses. They had a game, and music, and this.... He hands THE SHEET OF MANILA PAPER that was next to Sarah over to Isaac.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING
dialogues.text: Not a bad likeness of the thunderbird. Burt and Vicky, unmistakable, are standing next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac stares at the picture for what seems like a long ti Meditatively. Reflecting.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: They came already. He looks at Sarah with a hint of warmth.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: You have the gift of sight, child. This is a blessing. Sarah doesn't reply. She and Job are scared out of their wits.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: I have seen this car upon the road.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Go to the old man. Make sure he tells them nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: What about these two?  35. Sarah and Job stand absolutely rigid at attention. Maybe they don't catch anybody's eyes their worst fears won't b fulfilled. Isaac decides their fate.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: (calmly) Take them back where they were.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: But they had music! And a game! These things are forbidden!

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Question me not, Malachai. I act according to his will. Malachai withers under the reproach. He bows his head reverently, touches the deadly blade to it, and then turn Job and Sarah with that killing gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky are trying to make some sense of it all. Joseph's suitcase is on the seat between them.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: But why? Why would anybody do that to a...a kid?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He wasn’t that young. About 18 I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Could it have been an accident? Some kind of farm machine, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Not a wound like that. His throat was cut ear to ear. That was deliberate. He was already dead when I...when he stumbled into the road.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Whoever killed him...do you think he saw us? Burt doesn't answer.  36.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I felt like we were being watched.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Possibly. Blood starts to coagulate in four minutes, and the blood on the corn, even on the suitcase, was still fresh by the time I got to it.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Then the murderer might have been in there when you...Didn't you realize???

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I couldn't leave it there. Besides, I thought it might hold some clue.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Let's open it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No. Let's just get to a phone. Ora house. Or something for God's sakes. Even a trucker with a CB.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Funny how we haven't seen another car or truck.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We should be hitting this place Gatlin pretty soon.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I wonder if he lived there.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We may never know.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'd like to know. I think we have a right to know. In fact, maybe we ought to. Burt looks down at the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I guess it won't hurt to look.  37. Vicky immediately turns it around so that the locks are facing her. She reacts to all the blood.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Yech Burt reaches for the radio.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Maybe we can get some news. He hits the button just as Vicky gets the latches unlatch and starts to open the suitcase. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: ATONEMENT
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky both jump. The lid of the suitcase drops shut.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO PREACHER, (VO)
dialogues.text: Only by the blood of the lamb are we saved I Only by His watchful eye are we kept from the sins of the world! Burt turns the radio off with a punch. He shouts to the a

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I have enough of this shit.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (echoing) And does it get into the corn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car. The corn, and another sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky fishes through the suitcase, reaching underneath th top layer of CLOTHES. She finds something, and recoils in fright.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What is it?  38. She extracts and holds up for him to see A CORNCOB CRUCIF THE CHRIST FIGURE is done in raised relief, the kernels around it having been picked out. The cob has been cut in half lengthwise and notched at the top into a cross. It's monstrous corruption.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Not in my book.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That's an authentic American Primitive.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I think it's repulsive. Burt's eye catches something up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A VERY OLD MOBIL STATION, attested by the fact that the s out front bears the ancient RED PEGASUS LOGO and accompan FLYING A. There are two ANTIQUATED PUMPS on the island an a THIRD PUMP near the station house for DIESEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The t-bird turns into the station just in front of where main road veers off to the right and a SECONDARY ROAD jut off to the left. The secondary road is rutted and only tw lanes so that cars going opposite ways would have to cree past each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt drives over to where CHESTER DIEHL is working on a 6 CHEVY PICK-UP.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (the crucifix) Better put that away. No need to involve this guy. Vicky nods gravely in agreement. Burt touches her cheek gently.  39.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Everything'11 be alright The look in her eyes wants to believe him, and almost doe Burt exits the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester withdraws from the bowels of the pick-up. He's in late 60's, slow-moving and looks like an old prospector. bib overalls are stained with grease and his eyes are magnified tremendously by his thick glasses. He walks towards Burt. So does SARGE, an old HOUND DOG who barks a friendly greeting and jumps up on Burt. The dog's tail is wagging.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: At ease, Sarge. Maybe he don't want no beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge's collar has a cold can of OLD MILWAUKEE BEER attac to it where a Saint Bernard would have a keg. The dog bac off at Diehl's command. Burt pets him.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Next time, Sarge... (to Diehl) What I really need is...

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Don't got no gas.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh. No, I...

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Don't got no diesel neither. Tanks are dry. Expectin' the truck any day now.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That's alright. I just wanted to...

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Don't buy no gas, can't use the restrooms.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Telephone! I just want to use the phone I...  40. Diehl starts to reply but Burt knows what's coming and be him to it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Don't got no phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt looks to Vicky. Burt sighs heavily. Diehl takes a closer look at the stranger. Diehl squeals at Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He sees the flecks of dried blood on Burt's hands and clothes.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORN
dialogues.text: Cornfields surround the gas station. The stalks begin to rustle and sway, as if a wind or force were in them. This force is threatening and immensely powerful.

dialogues.speaker: GAS STATION
dialogues.text: Sarge picks up on this "presence." His ears prick up and growls deeply. This signals a change in Chester Diehl. He studies the dog for a moment, then seems to be anxious ab something although Burt can't quite figure out what. Mayb it's just that he starts to move faster. He gives Burt a cover-up smile.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Sarge, you be still now. In fact, why don't you go give that nice lady a Coke. Reluctant and whining, Sarge trots back towards the stati house. Diehl turns his attention to Burt. He points to th fork in the road.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: What you wanna do is go to Hemingford, Mister. About 19 miles down the right fork here. Can’t miss it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What about Gatlin?

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Ain't nothin’ in Gatlin... (mutters) Nothin' for you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIEHL(cont'd) (normal) You'll find everything you need in Hemingford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky is watching the men. Sarge POPS UP by her window, scaring the breath out of her. He is slobbering over a ca COKE that he holds in his mouth. He drops it in her lap. pats him on the head.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Thanks, fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever the hell is moving the corn around like that see to be getting closer to the station. The sky seems to dar and an eerie wind picks up.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING SARGE
dialogues.text: He still has his paws up on the car but is sniffing the a wildly. He barks loudly, again giving Vicky a bit of a fright, and clambers out towards the corn-field.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Diehl is definitely worried about something, and not only Sarge, on whom he's keeping a close watch.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Sarge, You stay right here!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'nothing for you in Gatlin?

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Well, folks in Gatlin got religion. They don't cotton to outsiders and you probably won't find a phone. He looks around Burt towards Sarge, who is whining and sniffing at the edge of the cornfield. Burt turns also.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: The corn in front of Sarge is waving vigorously in the "wind."  42.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Mister, I'd sure like to stay here and shoot the breeze with ya, talk about politics and farm futures, but right now I got work to do. You get on that right fork over there and you'll be in Hemingford in no time. (sudden, vehement ) Sarge! I said AT EASE!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Well thanks a lot. You've been a real help. Diehl watches as he gets back into the t-bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diehl is standing in front of the car, torn between apologizing to Burt and wanting to get back to Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Hey, you got a busted headlight, Mister. Looks like some blood on it. Burt leans out the window. Diehl is increasingly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: You have some kinda oxidant or somethin’?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Why? You have time to fix it for me? He's letting the old man know that he knows something is wrong here.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: No, but you can get it fixed.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: In Hemingford. Diehl nods affirmative with smile, then looks for Sarge. What he sees alarms him. He goes running towards the dog.  43.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Sarge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt pulls out of the station just a bit too fast. Someth about Diehl has agitated him.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Either that guy was terrified of something, or he's been out in the sun too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The t-bird drives up to the fork in the road, pauses momentarily, then takes the right fork towards Heming-for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge, barking feverishly, runs into the cornfield. Diehl arrives at the edge of the corn just a moment too late. H dares not follow even his beloved dog.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: (angst) Sarge! Sarge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It whips past a sign for GATLIN - 2 MILES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky has begun taking things out of the suitcase and fol them neatly on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: There's nothing much in here. Just kid's stuff. Clothes, a compass, a pocket knife, matches and an apple.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Smart kid. He must've figured he might have to sleep out a night or two. Vicky holds up a COLLEGE T-SHIRT with the NEBRASKA CORNHUSKERS and number 19 emblazoned on front. The though of it makes her start crying again.  44.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh, Burt...Look, maybe he was hoping to go to the university...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Might have been...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Why. ..Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The t-bird screeches to a halt as it COMES INTO FRAME. It BACKS UP TOWARDS THE CAMERA. From this angle, we can see WHITE SIGNPOST with GATLIN ROAD marked in BLACK LETTERS. stands at the corner of A TINY, ONE LANE ROAD that is not easily seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky consider the road through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: This has to go to Gatlin. Every sign we've seen has been for Gatlin and none for Hemingford. We can't be more than a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What about what the gas station guy said?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That crazy old coot. I can't believe there isn't a public phone in an entire town, I don't care how small it is.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Well, let's just do whatever's fastest. Burt drives forward and turns left onto Gatlin Road. It's EXTREMELY NARROW, even more claustrophobic than the one t were just on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester is still calling to Sarge, but, there's neither s nor sound of the dog. Diehl's call has become a lament.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Ah, Sarge...Why'd ya hafta go after ‘em... The only reply is the rustling of the corn.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING PICK-UP TRUCK
dialogues.text: THE HAND OF A CHILD pulls a cross-shaped lug wrench out o the back of the truck Diehl was working on when Burt and Vicky first drove up. The hand clangs the wrench against side of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING DIEHL
dialogues.text: He whips around, knowing he's heard something, but not se any sign of what it was. He looks back to the corn, as if call Sarge one last time, but is too bothered by the nois he's just heard. Instead, he takes a few tentative steps towards the pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: (fearful) Izzat you...Izzat you? What da - What are you doin’ in there? The answer he gets is ANOTHER NOISE, this time coming fro his office. He turns and faces that way, craning his neck see. His breath is quick. In a word, he's terrified. He takes a few steps towards the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corn all around the station is beginning to rustle ev more furiously than it had been.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: He approaches the office. Another few feet to go.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORN
dialogues.text: Still moving, weird and ominous.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Chester reaches for the office door. His hand is shaking. Just as it swings open we....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car comes to the top of a rise and Burt and Vicky are treated to a panorama of..MORE CORN. Burt puts on the bra

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Something's wrong. That last sign said Gatlin was one mile.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That sign was damaged in the last ice age.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It's got to be around here some- where.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (spooked) Why don't we just go back and take the road to Hemingford?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Because it's silly to go nineteen miles when you only need to go one. It's worse than silly. It's suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: When you have a body in the trunk....

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: And a broken headlight with blood on it. He proceeds on. 50 yards ahead is another left turn.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay, let's try this one. He turns onto yet a smaller road. They are going deeper a deeper into the corn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester Diehl breathes a sigh of relief. He's standing inside the door to his office and mercifully, he's alone. There's nothing but the usual mess.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Musta been the wind. And just as he says this there's a loud CRASH!

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Oh Lordy! Please be the wind! He exits the office, again taking those short, frightened tentative steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to the pick-up. He's whimpering softly, talking to himself, trying to keep his nerve.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: "Course it's the wind. Them hood latches ain't worth a damn. Blow over in a bad fart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the truck and starts fighting the hood, which stuck. Suddenly, the HUMMING we have heard before - pagan atonal and eerie - breaks the silence. Chester jerks arou but sees nothing. HE WALKS TOWARDS THE CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: Who is it? Who's there? I didn't tell them anything! I swear it! I kept our bargain, just like always! ! But the humming has stopped and no one appears. Diehl wai Nothing happens. By and by, he figures maybe this too was wind. Now he goes back to the truck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the hood with a mighty heave. As it opens, it reveals something that makes Chester Diehl scream.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: Sarge's head, cut off at a bloody stump of a neck, is res squarely on the engine. The eyes have rolled backwards an up and the beer can from his neck ring has been stuffed i his mouth, giving the decapitated beast a comically macab look. There's blood all over the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes Chester a moment to stop screaming. The shock ha caused him to stumble back, away from the truck. After a steps, he staggers around in circles, looking on every si for danger. He continues to move back until he comes to t garage bay door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's standing next to the door, looking around wildly, wh he spots a long handled WRENCH. He picks it up protective and waits. Nothing happens for a beat. Then, the bay door clatters up behind him and Chester whirls around, the wre raised over his head. He stares into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: You bastards I You killed my Sarge! I'll get you for what you done to him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The t-bird bounces along the tiny road. The corn seems to moving in on it; two giant, green walls about to crush a darting insect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Burt and Vicky are nervous now, spooked and disorien Both speak with a frantic edge in their voices.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: This isn't the way! I'm telling you!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It's got to be! We made a left and a left! They drive on further. Burt is intense, speaking to calm himself as well as Vicky.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: These roads are straight. No curves. If anything, this one has to let us out by the station. Vicky doesn't answer.  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to a wall of corn where the road ends in a perpendicular T. Burt squeals the brakes and he and Vicky hear things toppling in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It was just my golf bag.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'Am I sure?! Of course I'm sure!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I mean about the boy. Are you sure he was dead?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Vicky! He looks at the road in front, then behind them, trying t gauge their direction. He decides to go left again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can tell from the way the tires screech that Burt is a who is quickly losing control. The car fish-tails into th turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battle is going on, more like a kill with a pack of wil animals taunting their surrounded prey before they move i The garage bay is fairly large, strewn with old tires, bo oil cans, rags, hoses and various other instruments and acquisitions of the trade. In the center shiny red 1960 MERCURY SEDAN sits over the single LIFT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester Diehl is the surrounded animal and he isn't going down without a fight.  50. He is flailing wildly with 'his long handled wrench, tryi to hit the black clad children who dart in and out of his reach. They are all armed with farm tools. They are led b Malachai. Diehl focuses on him.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: You murderin' little devil. I done everything you said. I never told anyone. Not once in three years. He swings the wrench clumsily. Malachai steps sprightly o of the way. He can kill Diehl any time he wants.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: (contemptuous) Call yourself the Lord's Children.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: We do his bidding, from shine to shadow.

dialogues.speaker: DIEHL
dialogues.text: The devil’s!

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: He Who Walks Behind The Rows! Diehl swings again, this time causing himself to trip and stumble forward. Malachai kicks him backwards into a GROU his accomplices. They begin to beat and hack at the old m He scatters them with the wrench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The t-bird is chewing up road, barreling along at close t sixty. We get a sense from this shot of desperation, as i the vehicle itself were frightened. It rips over bumps, t and dips.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: It is strewn with corn silk and leaves, which cling despi the air drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky are silent. They come to another T. Burt h the brakes, suddenly coming to the realization that the c is his adversary.  51.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (losing it) Oh God! We're never going to get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Stop it, Vicky! We will too!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Then tell me where we are! He answers with another left turn.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Right back where we started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've turned onto a bigger road, one that looks vaguely familiar.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I think you're right! This looks like the first one we were on.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I told you. They continue along, picking up speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The t-bird comes hurtling TOWARDS THE CAMERA. As it fills the frame, it slows to a. halt. Burt and Vicky sit motionless, staring in disbelief at something that is BEH THE CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car doors open on both sides. Burt and Vicky get out move towards something OFF SCREEN. Their expressions show bewilderment and revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD
dialogues.text: In front of the car, we see the SWERVE MARKS where the ca tried to avoid Joseph. This is definitely the spot, The c from where he was murdered out to the road, is now an ooz blackened version of its former self. Where it was green strong (and bloody), it is now rotting and wilted. It has not been burned. Rather, it has become diseased and decay in this short period of time. This area has become a canc on the other-wise healthy, green landscape.  52.

dialogues.speaker: BURT AND VICKY
dialogues.text: stare at it, comprehending only on a subliminal level. Vicky.is cringing, beyond words. Burt steps forward. He looks at Vicky.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Her eyes have the look of a crippled gazelle that knows i being pursued by lions. She has somehow read her own deat sentence in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt walks over to her. He has found a reservoir of stren in all this horror. He rejects Vicky's obvious fatalism.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We're going back to that gas station. I want some answers, and I think that old man as them. We’re driving in circles. Let’s go back. Vicky gazes at him blankly; a frightened, hopeless look a her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls into the station. A quiet kind of danger pervades the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt gets out of the car resolutely but stays near it for safety. He scans all around. There's no sign of Chester, Sarge, or anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey! Old Timer! Nothing. He reaches in through the window and hits the ho

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I want to speak to you! Still no reply, unless the very loud silence counts.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) He's got to be around here some- where.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt walks over to the pick-up. He looks inside the cab then notices the hood is ajar, mostly down but with six inches of gap. Reflexively, he goes to lift it but before does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky gets out of the car and calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Maybe he's inside, in the bathroom or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt forgets the hood (and under it, Sarge's head) and wa around the side of the station to the door marked MEN. He knocks on it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hello? Anybody in there? Nothing. He tries the handle but it's locked. He walks ba towards the front office. Vicky meets him.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How about you wait in the car.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Not on your life.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Alright. But stay behind me. And keep your eyes open. They head for the office, Burt leading the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vicky enter the office. It is exactly as it was we saw Diehl in p.t except for one, glaring incongruity. THERE IS CORN EVERYWHERE. Ears, leaves, stalks and silk} piled on the desk, stuffed in the water cooler, heaped in garbage pail, etc. It is macabre, eerie. Vicky gasps; Bur tightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt puts his face up to the glass window on the door tha separates the office from the garage bay.  54. The bay is dark inside, and Burt had to wipe the dirt off window to see what little he can do. INT. GARAGE BAY - OFFICE DOOR - CAMERA’S POV The door between the bay and the office opens and, after brief hesitation, Burt and Vicky enter the dim room. It i illuminated from light coming from the outside and the office, but shadows fall everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt AND Vicky enter cautiously, making as little noise a possible. They look around. The place is a mess, having been torn apart during Diehl’s struggle wit the Children. Only THE MERCURY remains untouched, an island of stabilit amidst the destruction. Burt and Vicky move towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky’s elbow hits a HUBCAP on a WORKBENCH. It falls to t floor with a loud CLATTER! She and Burt jump simultaneous stifling their alarm the instant they realize what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reach the Mercury. Burt peers inside. INT. MERCURY - BURT’S POV Nothing. A nice red interior, an empty pack of Camels and loaded ashtray, but no bodies, bogeymen or Chester Diehl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky taps him on the shoulder. She points to a corn leaf protruding on a funny angle from the underneath the car. Burt kneels down and looks under the car. It is piled wit corn, which he tries to pull out but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt gets up the dust off his pants. Vicky looks at him quizzically. He doesn’t say anything, instead goes over t the LIFT CONTROL and pushes down the lever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Merc begins to float upwards as the hydraulic machine hums.  55.

dialogues.speaker: THE PIT
dialogues.text: The rising lift reveals THE BODY OF CHESTER DIEHL, bludge and bloody, lying dead in the pit. His body is festooned with corn plants and his arm, which is bent grotesquely a at an unnatural angle, holds aloft a hand that clutches another of the CORNCOB CRUCIFIXES. Vicky screams. Burt swoons. JOB’S VOICE OVER NARRATION COMPLETES THIS SCENE

dialogues.speaker: JOB, (VO)
dialogues.text: I think his name was Mr. Diehl, but once I heard Malachai say it was Judas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tries belong to the thunderbird, and it is getting as and as fast away from that gas station as is possible. Th rubber cries out for traction as the rpm’s exceed their ability to grip the asphalt. As a result, they protest wi blue smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car starts to follow the right fork again but suddenl jumps the triangular dirt divider and shoots onto the rut secondary road. Towards Gatlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arm of someone living is holding up a corncob crucifi CAMERA PULLS BACK and WE FIND OURSELVES at another religi gathering. There are about 50 BOYS AND GIRLS between the ages of 8 and 18, along with SEVERAL NEWBORN INFANTS. Everyone is dressed in black or gray except Isaac, who is one holding aloft the crucifix. The group is humming that bizarre chant we’ve now come to associate with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac is facing the others, about to lead a sermon. Behin him is the wooden base of what we will later see is a LAR CRUCIFIX. Isaac lowers his hand abruptly and the humming cuts off.  56.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Behold! A dream did come to me in the night and the Lord did shew all this to met

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Praise God. Praise the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: A time of tribulation has come. A test is at hand. The Final Test.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: What has the Lord commanded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac turns and looks up at the crucifix that towers behi him. CAMERA PANS UP, following his gaze, and we see the decaying body of a CRUCIFIED MAN on it. A few tattered BL RAGS of clothing hang off of it, and on the skeletal head a BLUE POLICE CHIEF hat. Most of the skin has been picked clean by crows, but the eyes are left, bulging and sightl The body has been festooned with dried corn leaves and co husks are piled around its feet like an offering.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: In the dream, the Lord did come to me, and He was a shape.
