He whacks the knife out of the boy's hand, then g him by the throat with his right hand (the bad shoulder s and raises the pipe over his head. He is completely in control of his dazed adversary. Malachai's life is in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt hesitates. He looks around at the circle of boys. Th don't know what to do. Burt's eyes are white hot with accusation.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Is this what you want? Another killing? Is this what your Isaac preaches? And almost as if in response, they hear Isaac's scream. I so inhuman that it distracts everyone, including Burt. Th scream is followed by ANOTHER NOISE, perhaps even more frightening and certainly less human. It's like the growl a lion, only much deeper and more potent, like water drai into a thousand foot well. It is a sound that is at once recognizable and yet unlike any we have ever heard. It should chill us to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVERAL OF THE BOYS runs away, so frightened are they by "declaration" from the cornfield. Burt rises to his feet, staring out at the darkness in awe and wonder. He forgets about Malachai, which is a mistake, and begins instinctiv to move towards the barn for Vicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malachai scrambles to his knees. He looks at the remainin boys.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAL
dialogues.text: Get him! Kill him! Nobody makes a move. Malachai is stunned that they would disobey him, but he is too filled with hate to worry abou that now. He sees his knife on the ground and picks it up Rising, he prepares to throw it into Burt's back. But jus as he does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VOICE calls out to him. It does not sound human.  111.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Malachai! Burt hears it too, and turns around to see Malachai, the remaining Children, and the figure who has stepped out of corn and is walking towards them.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: It is not Isaac, but once it was. This is a demon Isaac, hideous perversion of what used to be a little boy who wa possessed by a fanatical religion. Much of his skin has b eaten away - gnawed to the bone by some beast of nightmar His eyes are huge globes staring at something not of this world, as he is not any longer. His hair, the wisps of it that are left, seem more like corn leaves and corn silk, indeed there is a greenish tinge to what little skin he h left. His clothes are plastered with corn plants and smea with kernels. His hands, reaching outstretched for Malach are bone.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: He wants you too, Malachai! He wants you too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The half dozen Children left run past Burt into the barn. couple remain behind him and watch from the safety of his presence.

dialogues.speaker: MALACHAI
dialogues.text: He starts backing up. Alone. The look on his face is not demonstrable terror, or horror, or fright. It is way beyo that, so far that there is little emotion left with which express what it is. He's trembling and sweating profusely His hands and feet are like lead. He tries to flee from t oncoming demon but he can't seem to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac catches up to Malachai, hissing and growling like a animal as he leaps upon him. Malachai buries his knife up the hilt in Isaac's chest, but it doesn't even faze the smaller "boy." Isaac is already long since dead. He drags Malachai back into the corn with irresistible strength. Malachai's screams echo through the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt turns to the barn and sees that Vicky has witnessed spectacle.  112. The Children who ran into the barn are huddled around her She meets Burt halfway to the barn and they embrace passionately.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Thank God you're alright. Job and Sarah come running over to them. They're terribly upset by what they've just seen and they cling to Burt an Vicky. But just when you thought it was safe to go back i the corn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, Vicky and the children are physically jarred by the power of the roar. The monstrous sounds continue as light and lightning shatter the darkness, accompanied by a ragi wind that tosses debris in every direction. It's as if th monster is going to destroy the entire town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our "family" hurries to the relative safety of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, Vicky, Job and Sarah join the other six Children wh are huddled in here, frightened out of their wits.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I don't know. If I knew what it was out there maybe I could tell you.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: It's He Who Walks Behind the Rows.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What if we run for it. Try to make it to the road. Burt looks at the children, and Vicky's wounds.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I think we're safer here, at least for the time being. They listen as the horrendous noises continue outside. Th are slamming up against the barn walls.  113. Without warning, one of the planks explodes. The wind how in, muffling their screams of terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt goes to Job. Something has to be done.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Job, has anybody ever tried to hurt the monster? Any of the parents or adults, before they were. Job remembers what happened to them. To his parents.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: (quietly) The Blue Man.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Who's the Blue Man? what did he do?

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Officer Hotchkiss. The Chief of Police. He came down here after he talked to the minister. He was reading a page torn out of the bible. And then he was doing something with the still.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What stopped him?

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Malachai.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Why was he reading from the bible? What was it? Job reaches into his pocket. He pulls out a COMPASS, a PE KNIFE, a RABBIT'S FOOT KEY CHAIN, TWO BASEBALL CARDS, and WALLET. He pores through a number of PAPERS he has in the wallet. Outside, the sounds of Armageddon. The barn rocks and sways to the side.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Job! Job finally finds what he's looking for. He hands Burt th page from three years ago.  114.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAGE
dialogues.text: It's from REVELATIONS, CHAPTER 20. VERSE 10 is circled in RED. 20:10 And the devil that deceived them was cast into the lake of fire and brimstone, where the beast and the false prophet are, and shall be tormented day and night for ever and ever. Burt remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just after the black-robed girl stabbed Burt and he fell the pile of bibles, he noticed a page had been torn from of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt fights his frustration. He looks at Vicky, who has read the page over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I don't know what it means! Another plank explodes. And another. They duck out of the way of the splintering boards.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (shouting, to Job) What was the Blue Man doing at the still?

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: He hooked the hose up to it and was rolling it out. Burt ponders.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Lake of fire...Fire! He must have been trying to burn the field.  115.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: But how?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: With the...Never mind. Burt springs into action. He becomes the Field General of this motley fighting force.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You kids I Get me all the hoses you can find. Job, Sarah, find a glass bottle, a soda pop bottle if you can. Vicky, come here. Burt leads Vicky over to the GASOHOL DRUMS. He takes the from one of the kids. It won't connect to the spigot

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to kid) Give me your knife. The innocent looking boy hands Burt a mean looking knife. Burt hands it to Vicky and holds up the hose.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Cut it. She does so. Burt jams the end onto the spigot.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) You're going to have to hold this tight when I go out there.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Where??? What??? Are you crazy??? Burt ignores her. He barks an order at the kids.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Connect those hoses. Hurry! Job arrives with an empty, ancient bottle of PEPSI. Burt takes the hose off the spigot long enough to fill the bot with gasohol. He rips part of Job's shirt and stuffs the into the bottle. Job protests.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: Hey!  116. Burt smiles and touches the boy's cheek as he shakes the bottle thoroughly, wetting the rag with the gasohol. He turns to Vicky and gives her a hard, sudden kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I love you. Remember to keep that hose on tight. He jams it up against the spigot and opens the valve. Vic doesn't know what to say, so she says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt lights the rag with his cigarette lighter, picks up hose, from which gasohol is beginning to pour out, and ex the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scene worthy of the sounds we have just heard from insi the barn. There's a gale force wind blowing out of the cornfield. Wood, glass, corn - all kinds of debris - are being tossed about. The sky is dark but darker over the cornfield, except for the middle which is glowing and sparking. The houses and buildings of Gatlin are coming apart, both from the wind and the noise, that incredible chilling roar, emanating from the cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt runs with the hose and the Molotov cocktail towards sprinkler pump fixture. An even more savage roar goes up from the monster. Things begin to come out of the field, shot as if from cannons, right at Burt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first the corn plants seem like debris. They whip arou Burt's legs, tripping him, and around his arms. While he' struggling, more are piling on top of him. He's becoming entangled in a net. Panic stricken, Burt struggles to fre himself. He's tearing at the stalks when he sees...

dialogues.speaker: THE BLUE MAN AND HIS CROSS
dialogues.text: The crucifix and its dead occupant are about to smash Bur into the ground. He rolls out of the way just in time, barely avoiding the ten foot wooden icon. But he is still entangled in the corn stalks. Job suddenl appears with a knife. He starts hacking away at the stalk They bleed and the monster howls in protest.  117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is free. He picks up the hose and cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Get back to the barn! He runs forward. Job stays right where he is, not wanting abandon Burt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is almost at the pump when THE BODIES OF ISAAC AND MALACHI - what's left of them - are now flung upon him. H skeletons, half decaying flesh, they entangle him ina lifeless grappler hold. Burt struggles to rid himself of them and finds it isn't that easy.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: He stands frozen, watching in horror.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD
dialogues.text: And now the monster itself rears its head and bellows its intent. It is immense, formless, a vision of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is working feverishly. He opens the metal cover on t pump and tries to unscrew its connecting valve. The thing won't budge. The hose is spilling gallons of gasohol by t second and is in danger of running out. He grabs another piece of loose tubing and uses it as a lever. The valve finally opens. Job arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monster moves slowly, steadly, inexorably towards Bur and Job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt jams the hose into the valve. He throws the switch and...

dialogues.speaker: CORNFIELD
dialogues.text: ...Nothing happens. The monster approaches. Burt and Job will never make it back to the barn. The Beast is too clo But then, the sprinklers begin to move, kicked to life by sudden increase in pressure. They begin to spew gasohol o the sacred corn.  118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beast is enraged. It looses a deafening roar of prote and pain. It lifts the giant sprinklers into the air like they were toys and thrashes them, but as it does so it on gets more of the fluid on the corn, and also on itself.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Burt picks up the Molotov cocktail and heaves it. Within motion, though, he is jolted by the forgotten pain in his wounded shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Molotov cocktail falls far short of its target. In fa it doesn't even break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, clutching his wound, stares in shock.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh no.... Job, realizing what has happened, begins to run straight the corn.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Job! NO! COME BACK!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job is intent. His little body darts into the rows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monster starts towards the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt starts towards the field, screaming to Job in vain.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN THE ROWS
dialogues.text: Job flies past the stalks. He spots the still-burning cocktail.  119.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He scours the field with his eyes. Despair racks his body As the Beast comes within 50 yards, its immense shadow fa over him. Burt steps back, his eyes drawn upwards. He is about to die and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job emerges from the cornfield. He hands the flaming Molo cocktail to Burt, who is so happy to see him that he forg himself for a moment. He looks at the boy, and then incredulously at the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: JOB
dialogues.text: He waits expectantly for Burt to throw it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt heaves the cocktail as hard and as high as he can. I takes a second for it to land and then..

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD EXPLODES IN FLAME
dialogues.text: becoming a veritable LAKE OF FIRE. The sky turns a fiery orange-red. THE BEAST HOWLS EVEN LOUDER, registering its and rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky and the rest of the children venture a look, so gre is the noise and the heat.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (seeing the flames) Oh my God! Buuuurrrrrt! She goes running to him, all of the Children following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Job have been running towards the barn. They joi the others and all continue their retreat to a safer plac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop near the edge of town and look back on the destruction.  120.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD
dialogues.text: The Devil is in his Hell. As the flames consume the field MUCH BRIGHTER AND MORE INTENSE FIRE accompanied "by tortu screaming, breaks off from the general one. The Beast is outlined and defined by this fire within the fire. It bur brighter and brighter, brilliantly for a moment, and then IMPLODES IN ON ITSELF, turning into a vortex that disappe down into the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, Vicky, Job and Sarah, and all of the others, watch, glow from the continuing flames casting a healing light o their faces. Vicky is leaning against Burt. In her hand, is still clutching the page from Revelations. -end-
